subject: Modern Perl Released! - Startup Row at YAPC::NA - Get the Perl Weekly every day
header: Next week I'll be on vacation in the Alps, skiing with my children. We'll be in a house without Internet access so this means, most likely I am going to skip next weeks issue.
OTOH I have started to distribute links as I read them via 3 social networks. If you are interested, see the explanation below.
In the meantime, enjoy the news of this issue:

entries.title: Perl is more viable for web development than ever!
entries.text: Joel Berger wrote a new entry to an old question on StackOverflow and by asking for the support of the community quickly raised to be the number one answer. This is a motivational article. Go and build a web application in Perl!

entries.title: The Case of the Overloaded Curlys
entries.text: C. Auguste Dupin helping Tom Wyant in a Perl parsing problem. Brilliant.

entries.title: Startup Row
entries.text: JT Smith writes, that YAPC::NA is planning to allocated free booth space to Perl based Startup companies. If you are working for one of them, let your management know about this opportunity.

entries.title: Modern Perl 2011-2012 Edition Released!
entries.text: Last week I already mentioned, but I think it is worth mentioning again now, that you can pre-order the book.

entries.title: Minimalistic data validation with Validate::Tiny
entries.text: Stefan, the minimalist introduces his new module that allows easy data validation.

entries.title: ASUS EPU-6 utility hacked with Win32::GuiTest
entries.text: Dmitry Karasik mentioned the utility he wrote to automate some small application on MS Windows using a Perl script. Code included.

entries.title: s/ZeroMQ.pm/ZMQ.pm/g
entries.text: Daisuke Maki (lestrrat) has released a new binding to zero.mq usng the opportunity to change the name of the Perl module as well.

entries.title: Simple Todo List Processing in Perl
entries.text: Mark Fowler explains his TODO processor along with the extract function which is a bit like a two-way grep.

entries.title: London Perl Workshop: The Videos
entries.text: Mark Keating posted a link to the recently finished videos from LPW 2011.

entries.title: Looking back, looking forward
entries.text: Jonathan Worthington is looking around himself, and especially at the progress Perl 6 made in the last year and his plan for the next year.

entries.title: Last Piece of Pi
entries.text: Solomon Foster (colomon) tells us about his Perl 6 project that a year ago lacked the implementation in both Rakudo and Niecza but today ...

entries.title: How to get the Perl Weekly every day?
entries.text: If you'd like to get the news of Perl weekly even earlier, or if you'd like to recommend individual posts, you can do that through any of 3 social networks.

entries.title: Use of uninitialized value
entries.text: Perl can provide various warnings and errors that can be very unclear to people who are new to perl. In this article I try to explain the 'Use of uninitialized value' warning.

entries.title: How to read a CSV file using Perl?
entries.text: When parsing an CSV file one would probably start using split() just to find out soon that it only works in simple cases. For more complex cases Text::CSV_XS is a much better solution.
